channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. and Allies Condemn Putin’s Troop Mobilization and Nuclear Threats
item.description: Biden administration officials vowed to continue sending military, economic and humanitarian aid to help Ukraine defend itself against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: White House and Pentagon officials said the Russian president’s threats would not stall efforts by the Biden administration to continue funneling military aid to Ukrainian forces.

item.title: The Fed made another supersize rate increase as it struggles to contain rapid inflation.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: How the Car Market Is Shedding Light on a Key Inflation Question
item.description: How easily companies give up swollen profits could determine how easily the Federal Reserve can cool inflation. Dealerships offer clues.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Car dealers have been paying higher inventory costs but charging consumers even more, earning record profits.

item.title: What Fed Rate Increases Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
item.description: Savers will benefit and borrowers can expect to pay more on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard

item.title: Trump Is Sued for Fraud By New York State A.G. Letitia James
item.description: The New York attorney general, Letitia James, is seeking to bar the Trump family from ever operating in the state again.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich, William K. Rashbaum and Ben Protess
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although the lawsuit against Donald J. Trump cannot include criminal charges, the former president could face substantial financial penalties.

item.title: The Political Backdrop of Letitia James’s Lawsuit Against Trump
item.description: New York’s attorney general tried to downplay the politics hanging over the lawsuit, while allies of former President Donald J. Trump did the opposite.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:description: Letitia James, the New York attorney general, announcing the Trump lawsuit on Wednesday in Manhattan. “This has nothing to do with politics,” she said of her investigation this summer. “It has to do with the law.”

item.title: Trial of Former Trump Adviser Begins With Opening Statements
item.description: Thomas Barrack is accused by prosecutors of acting as an undisclosed agent for the government of the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Barrack, prosecutors say, tried to sway administration policy to favor his patrons.

item.title: House Passes Overhaul of Electoral Count, Moving to Avert Another Jan. 6 Crisis
item.description: The legislation, opposed by most Republicans, is a bid to update the law that former President Donald J. Trump tried to exploit on Jan. 6, 2021, to invalidate his defeat.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence and Speaker Nancy Pelosi presiding over the counting of Electoral College votes in the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The legislation would define the vice president’s role as strictly ministerial.

item.title: TikTok’s Corn Kid Is Doing Just Fine
item.description: He went viral this summer for his love of corn. Now it’s back to business as usual: elementary school.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: A video of Tariq, 7, took off online when he shared his love of corn.

item.title: How ‘Lord of the Rings’ Inspires Italy’s Giorgia Meloni
item.description: Giorgia Meloni, the nationalist politician who is the front-runner to become prime minister, sees “The Lord of the Rings” as not just a series of novels, but also a sacred text.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: As a youth activist, Giorgia Meloni revered “The Lord of the Rings” and other works by the British writer J.R.R. Tolkien.

item.title: Drenched by Hurricane Fiona, Puerto Ricans Band Together
item.description: Neighbors are moving ruined appliances and, with brooms and shovels, wiping away the mud that coats their homes. They learned from Hurricane Maria not to wait for official help.
item.dc:creator: Laura N. Pérez Sánchez
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the help of her family, María Cortés Dávila cleaned her home after Hurricane Fiona dumped rain on Toa Baja, P.R. Some parts of the island received 30 inches.

item.title: In New Film, Former Employee Says Mario Batali Sexually Assaulted Her
item.description: A woman who worked for the chef comes forward with her account of a night at the Spotted Pig in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin and Kim Severson
item.category: Batali: The Fall of a Superstar Chef (Movie)
item.media:description: It took five years after the #MeToo movement began for Eva DeVirgilis, who worked for Mario Batali, to go public with her account.

item.title: See Images of Neptune Come Into Focus With Webb Telescope
item.description: New images from the space-based observatory offer a novel view of the planet in infrared.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O’Callaghan
item.media:description: Neptune with its rings and several of its moons clearly visible, as captured by the James Webb Space Telescope’s Near Infrared Camera.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Bold Ventures,’ by Charlotte Van den Broeck
item.description: Charlotte Van den Broeck’s “Bold Ventures” is an idiosyncratic tour of architectural misfires, dotted with its author’s personal anxieties.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.category: Bold Ventures: Thirteen Tales of Architectural Tragedy (Book)
item.media:description: The twisted spire on the 400-year-old Church of St. Omer in Verchin, France, which embarrassed the chief mason who built it.

item.title: Three Paths Toward an Endgame for Putin’s War
item.description: But here are three possibilities.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man painting over the Russian flag in a recently recaptured Ukrainian village.

item.title: Inside the Completely Legal G.O.P. Plot to Destroy American Democracy
item.description: Imagine a legal January 6. It’s bureaucratic, boring, invisible, and it might actually succeed.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Harris and Michelle Cottle

item.title: Are There Better Places to Put Large Solar Farms Than These Forests?
item.description: For the great promise of renewable energy to be realized, states like Virginia must create an environment where solar, nature and people can peaceably coexist.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel Popkin
item.media:credit: Melissa Lyttle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twitty’s Creek Solar, a 134-acre, 15-megawatt installation along Highway 59, is the first solar project operating in Charlotte County, Va.

item.title: My Teachers Made Me Who I Am
item.description: In the midst of a debate about the content being presented in America’s schools, the equally pressing issue of how teachers teach is in danger of being lost.
item.dc:creator: Esau McCaulley

item.title: ‘We Can’t Let the Kids Go Outdoors’: Our New Reality on the West Coast
item.description: For children there, it isn’t a question of what you want to do outside; it’s whether it is even safe to leave the house.
item.dc:creator: Emma Pattee

item.title: The Border Crisis Could Still Be Biden’s Opportunity
item.description: But first it would help to admit that the border is not secure.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: Despite the Covid disruption, school test score declines look pretty modest
item.description: Despite the Covid disruption, school test score declines look pretty modest.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: The Midlife Crisis Is Very Real and Nothing to Be Laughed At
item.description: It may be a result of our affluent world. Or it may be biological.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: A Shrinking Margin
item.description: Democrats lost ground with Hispanic voters in 2020. It doesn’t seem to have been a blip.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Trump in 2020 at a Latinos for Trump event in Phoenix.

item.title: How Border Politics Landed in Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: Two conservative governors are trying to make undocumented immigration a problem for blue states, not just red ones.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, Mooj Zadie, Will Reid, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother and daughter who were among the migrants flown to Martha’s Vineyard from Florida taking in the view last week as a ferry left the island.

item.title: ‘Serial’: Season 1
item.description: “Serial” is a podcast from the creators of “This American Life," hosted by Sarah Koenig. “Serial” tells one story — a true story — over the course of a season.
item.dc:creator: Serial Productions

item.title: Dates With a Book, Meals for Roller Skaters and More Reader Requests
item.description: Looking to celebrate a quiet birthday on your own? No problem.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson

item.title: Robert Sarver to Tell Phoenix Suns and Mercury Teams Amid Scandal
item.description: Robert Sarver, the majority owner of the N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. teams in Phoenix, had been fined $10 million and suspended for using racist slurs and mistreating employees for years.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola, Tania Ganguli and Kevin Draper
item.media:description: Robert Sarver, who owns the Phoenix Suns, had been under investigation by the N.B.A. since November.

item.title: Senate Ratifies Kigali Amendment, the Global Pact to Curb Hydrofluorocarbons
item.description: In a bipartisan vote, lawmakers voted to join an international agreement to phase out the hydrofluorocarbons commonly found in refrigerators and air-conditioners.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
item.category: Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Air-conditioners in New Delhi in April. The Kigali Amendment of 2016 aims to sharply reduce the use of planet-warming refrigerants known as hydrofluorocarbons.

item.title: Protests in Iran Intensify Over Woman Who Died in Custody
item.description: Unrest has spread to dozens of cities, with at least seven people killed, according to witnesses, rights groups and video posted on social media.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran on Thursday. Unrest erupted last weekend after Mahsa Amini died in police custody following an arrest under the law on head scarves.

item.title: Space Force Song Shoots for the Stars, but Some Think It Falls Flat
item.description: It was a familiar scenario for the fledgling military branch, which has been the butt of jokes and TV satire.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Members of the United States Air Force Band singing “Semper Supra,” the new U.S. Space Force service song, in National Harbor, Md., on Tuesday.

item.title: Speeding Up Your Daily Walk Could Have Big Benefits
item.description: In the largest study to incorporate activity tracker data, picking up the pace paid dividends for long-term health.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Cardio and Strength Training May Help You Live Longer, Study Says
item.description: A consensus is building among experts that both strength training and cardio‌ are important for longevity.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank

item.title: Breaking Up With Peloton
item.description: The stationary bike’s convenience made it a pandemic winner, but some former fans are done working out at home.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: The Artist Who Throws Newton a Curve
item.description: The Orange County Museum of Art inaugurates its new building with a tribute to Fred Eversley, an unheralded pioneer of the Light and Space movement.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets
item.media:credit: Elliott Jerome Brown Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: The sculptor Fred Eversley alongside one of his parabolic lenses that is installed on the ground floor of his five-story building in Manhattan’s SoHo neighborhood.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
